Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Enabling Quantum Leap: Exceptional-point Topological Polaritonics for Room-temperature Quantum Logic
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical description: This EAGER project seeks to enable room-temperature quantum logic operation in an emerging platform known as two-dimensional quantum materials. While quantum technologies present exciting opportunities such as exponential speed-ups of large computations, their realizations often require cryogenic conditions, such as -269 degrees Celsius, which is challenging to obtain in daily lives. Accordingly, the research team proposes to investigate, theoretically and experimentally, a set of fundamental physical mechanisms and phenomena that can significantly reduce the threshold of quantum logic gates and bring them to room-temperature operation. This research activity is integrated with efforts to train undergraduate and graduate students via interdisciplinary, collaborative research at the forefront of optical and quantum physics, material science, and nanotechnology.

Technical description: The interaction between light and matter is at the heart of both quantum logic gates and classical optoelectronic devices. So far, most research is built upon the traditional theoretical framework of cavity quantum electrodynamics, which relies on one assumption: the Green's function of a system can be fully expanded by its eigenmodes. In this project, the research team propose to investigate new physics and devices where this fundamental assumption fails, at a unique type of non-Hermitian topological degeneracies known as exceptional points. In particular, the project focuses on the application of exceptional points to reduce quantum logic thresholds in the platform of two-dimensional materials. Successful completion of the project may benefit society by potentially granting access to quantum technologies in people's daily lives. In addition, the focus on non-Hermiticity and topological physics enables the development of new families of classical optoelectronic devices essential to our technological infrastructure in a multitude of areas, including imaging and sensing, healthcare, and energy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Scientific merits

Through this EAGER program, we were able to make the following scientific discoveries and technical advances:

1. Improved synthesis of quantum materials

a. Controlled Growth of Large-Area Bilayer TMDs with Lateral P?N Junctions  

For stacks of homogeneous quantum materials, the number of layers plays a crucial role in their quantum properties. We develop a reliable method for growth of bilayer transition metal dichalcogenide flakes by tuning the composition of the growth promoter during chemical vapor deposition. We discovered that an optimized mixture of promoters enabled control of layer number in TMD flakes. The resulting bilayer WSe2 has high material quality with a single-crystal size > 40 μm. The majority of the bilayer regions displayed twist angles of 0? (AB) or 60? (AA′), whereas Moiré 15 and 30? twist angles were also observed. This method paves the way to future growth of quantum materials to be used as room-temperature quantum gates (described below).

b. Atomic-scale patterning in quantum superlattices 

Using the obtained bilayer TMDs, we demonstrated the localized layer-by-layer thinning and formation of nanopores/defects in 2D superlattices using aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy. Controlled electron beam irradiation is used to locally thin superlattices by removing the bottom layer of atoms, followed by defect formation through ablation of the second layer of atoms. The resulting defects exhibit atomically-sharp pore edges with tunable diameters down to 0.6 nm. Structural periodicities and focused STEM irradiation are also utilized to form close-packed nanopore arrays in superlattices with varying twist angles and commensurability. Applying these methods and mechanisms provides a forward approach in the atomic-scale patterning of stacked 2D quantum devices.

2. Optical characterizations of candidates for room-temperature quantum gates

a. Valleytronics: High valley degree of polarization in vdW hetero-bilayer 

Valley degree of freedom in 2D quantum material has been proposed to be good candidates for room-temperature quantum bits. Recent theoretical work also suggests the possibility to control interlayer excitons and achieve high valley polarization (pure qubits). However, reported valley polarization of interlayer excitons has been low, varying between 10% and 35%. Recently, we eliminate the extrinsic mechanisms with a high-quality, precisely rotationally aligned and hexagon-boron nitride (hBN) encapsulated WSe2/MoSe2 bilayer of a mere 6 meV linewidth. Through thorough characterization of the bilayer, we demonstrate spin singlet and triplet excitons with very high VPs over 80%, in opposite helicities.

b. Moire polaritons for potential room-temperature quantum gates 

The hybrid excitons feature simultaneously a static dipole momentum and large oscillator strength, making them ideal candidates to room-temperature quantum gates. Recently, we demonstrate the first strong coupling of photon with Moire excitons. Remarkably, the zero-dimensional nature of the moir? excitons manifests in distinctly different dependence of the polariton modes on the excitation density, providing a new route to achieve exceptionally high polariton nonlinearity in room-temperature materials. The results pave the way for using the Moir? lattice to understand, exploit, and control rich quantum optical effects. 

3. Novel physical phenomena that can enable new quantum gates and communication channels

a. Lossless and reconfigurable classical and quantum communication channels  

Communication between qubits often happens via photons. Recently, we propose a new type of communication channels, enabled by topological phases in nonlinear optical systems, which can always have perfect efficiency even in the presence of disorder. Furthermore, as these communication channels are defined by optical nonlinearity, they can also be reconfigured after fabrication, giving rise to more flexibility in constructing quantum networks.

b. Synthetic gauge fields that can potentially enable geometric quantum gates 

Particles placed inside an Abelian (commutative) gauge field can acquire different phases when traveling along the same path in opposite directions. Such behaviors can get significantly enriched for a non-Abelian gauge field, where even the ordering of different paths cannot be switched. So far, real-space realizations of gauge fields have been limited to Abelian ones. Recently, we report the first experimental synthesis of non-Abelian gauge fields in real space and the observation of the non-Abelian Aharonov-Bohm effect with classical waves and classical fluxes. Our work introduces real-space building blocks for non-Abelian gauge fields, which can enable classical and quantum exotic topological phenomena and also quantum geometric gates.   

Broader impact

Through this EAGER program, we demonstrated new physical phenomena and technical advancements that can potentially enable a broader class of room-temperature quantum logic devices. Our results will greatly benefit the society by potentially granting access to quantum technologies in people?s daily lives. In addition, our results can also improve new families of classical optoelectronic devices that are essential to our technology infrastructure in a multitude of areas, including information and communications, imaging and sensing, and healthcare. Finally, about 10 undergraduate and graduate students were trained through this program, who can drive future advancements in photonics, material sciences, and engineering.
